Author: Malti#3948
Content:
I always had my eye on Ark and Stratis next to Komodo as they are also more than a cryptocurrency (aiming for ecosystem/BaaS). Stratis used to be a top 20 coin iirc and Ark mostly floating around KMD.. Looking at those now, STRAT spot 99 and ARK  spot 122... 

KMD keeping that top 50 spot pretty consistently is an undervalued fact imo..

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: considering there have been literally thousands of new projects in the last 2 years, indeed, maintaining the ~50 ranking is indeed quite an underrated achievement. former top 20 projects typically end up on page 2 or 3 or 4, unless they have a lot of support. as poorly as STRAT and ARK seem to have done, it is much better than coins like BLK, XCP and so many others. and of course with KMD actually climbing the ranks, it is a very power sign

Author: Malti#3948
Content: agreed, that's why I take the example of ARK and STRAT as they are not your typical 'shitcoins' that actually deserve to fade away

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i only do the cli stuff, which most people dont really care about

Author: Malti#3948
Content: I thought you just stood up one day and decided nSPV had to be created? üòâ

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: actually i was reading the flyclient mathpaper, or trying to, and instead of deciphering what all the complex math was, it just seemed easier to create a simple solution to the same problem

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: such events cannot be planned for, nor predicted

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i do however have a history of solving problems

Author: Markus#5464
Content: @jl777c what is kmds goal then? i mean to me it seems like kmd is expanding in every possible corner, gaming, wallets and what not

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: goal?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: solving the ultimate issue that faces crypto

Author: Markus#5464
Content: Alright

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: achieving global adoption without being regulated to death, which requires not only tech, but the proper tech that is immune from regulations. luckily the fully decentralized model is both. it is 1000x+ harder to make fully decentralized solutions, which is why it takes so long, but now there is enough infrastructure in place to be able to solve all the remaining issues

Author: Markus#5464
Content: I think dpow is a really clever thing but do u ever think of a even better solution that would protect in similar way but not having to spend btc?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: without spending BTC, you cant get BTC transactions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: without BTC transactions, you cannot benefit from BTC hashrate

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once a problem is solved satisfatorily, then i dont spend much time trying to improve it more, especially as there are many areas that dont have any solutions at all yet

Author: Markus#5464
Content: true thats why i meant are u ever considering some alternative solution that gives similar lvl of protection but does not have to do with btc?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nothing comes close to BTC security. nothing

Author: Markus#5464
Content: Ok

Author: Malti#3948
Content: and isn't dPoW 'swapable'? imagine LTC would take over, KMD can notarize to the LTC chain right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once all the various parts are all in place and there is a viable full spectrum solution, then the weakest link can be improved and this process iterated

Author: Malti#3948
Content: could we notarize to a PoS chain if needed?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, the destination chain wont be hard to change as long as it is a bitcoin protocol. but if you are waiting for LTC (or even BCH) to overtake BTC... you have many years (decades) as it is extremely unlikely

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the problem with PoS chains is there is no external reference

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is all self-referential

Author: Malti#3948
Content: anyway, the problem isn't here right now

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so with a PoS chain, everything will be ok, until a catastrophic failure. PoW fails in a predictable 51% attack way, which are bad, but transitory. a PoS chain once compromised, stays compromised

Author: Malti#3948
Content: hmm, correct. Never thought if this.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and since the entire point of dPoW is to add as much security as possible, having a failure mode being a total catastrophic failure in the secure chain it seems unwise

Author: Malti#3948
Content: Do you get excited over the marketing campaign in any way? Isn't it nice to see all the tech you and the team have created communicated in a new way?

Content: glad that more people can understand the scope of what is already achieved

Content: no one

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: Is it not a maximalist worldview to think in terms of monopolistic 'mass adoption'? what is wrong with a multitude of independent, parallel systems?

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: when is winblows competitor to open source like linux

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess it isnt so unexpected but it seems a majority of people still view KMD as just a zcash fork privacy coin. so when the rebranding takes effect and people realize that KMD has totally transformed itself, we could indeed see a totally different market perception of it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @Lumbi when did i ever say mass adoption would happen with a single system?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: clearly global mass adoption cannot rely on a single blockchain, else its failure is like a centralized cloudfare blocking 42% of the internet

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with komodo, unlimited numbers of systems can be created to both allow mass market scaling, while at the same time be immune from any single system failure. we do need to get more source level forks for true immunity, but there are already a few such networks and once there is a proliferation of such chains, then it truly becomes unstoppable. any single component could be disabled at any given time, but not across all the systems

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is open source and a lot of projects are already copying what we do. in the larger sense that is a good thing, gives the crypto ecosystem more resilience, while solving the mass adoption problem in a practical way

Author: Markus#5464
Content: What would it take to overload the kmd blockchain and can it be a possible threat in the future if millions of ppl  start to transact on kmd daily?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and all the traders wanting some KMD tax to monetize this ... i guess some long term ecosystem explanation doesnt make sense to them? yet, how many silicon valley companies run at losses of billions for years, just to build up userbase. so think of KMD as in the building userbase stage. once we have a sufficient number of users, then monetizations can be added in ways that dont affect the user experience too much

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we can always spin up KMD sidechains if the KMD usages becomes too big and blocks are getting full (after doubling blocksize again)

Author: Markus#5464
Content: ok

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what about google?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how much did they charge for searches?

Author: Malti#3948
Content: is it?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: imaging their current marketshare if each search cost money

Author: Malti#3948
Content: how long were they making losses?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: uber is still losing billions

Author: Malti#3948
Content: and they IPO'd

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: google spent many years without any revenues

Author: Malti#3948
Content: blows my mind

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the model of komodo is to gain userbase as much as possible, and then figure out ways of monetizing in the optimal way. like for atomicDEX, we give KMD a 10% discount on the dexfee

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is a benefit for using KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: instead of a tax for using KMD

Author: Malti#3948
Content: so during the tech development, you are actively thinking about the monetization question as well?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when you are driving across many countries, do you worry much about what parking spot you will use after you are done driving the thousands of km?

Author: Malti#3948
Content: lol, how do you come up with these comparisons üòÜ

Author: Malti#3948
Content: but okay, true

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you asked, it is what came to mind. likely colored by the earlier roadmap question

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what is monetization?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is just adding some fee to an action that users perform, right?

Author: Malti#3948
Content: that's one way

Author: Malti#3948
Content: or selling data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the value of monetization is sum across all time of useractions *fee

Author: LocoMB#8593
Content: I think google did have a rather low burn rate in its first years (can't cite numbers right now)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: clearly we wont be selling the data that we are not gathering

Author: Malti#3948
Content: I know, but fees are not the only way to make money, that was just my point üòÉ

Author: Malti#3948
Content: (can I take that bit to make a tweet?)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the difficulty of adding monetization is the difficulty of adding a vout -> fee address to transactions that users make, in a way that users can accept as reasonable and not reduce usage

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is literally a few hours work to add and test

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: compared to the years of work it takes to build userbase

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and if you add fees before there is a big userbase, it most likely will prevent you from getting any big userbase

Author: Malti#3948
Content: that is true

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is why EOS gets the usage it gets as it is free for users, but they charge the developers and arm and a leg or two

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with komodo, the users might be charged fees or not, it is up to each project, but usually whatever fee would be denominated in a relatively low cost coin

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and out of all the various projects, the best ones will rise to the top

Author: Malti#3948
Content: so basically the strategy is: get as much people as possible on board and then you'll figure out how to monetize

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in the gold rush, the only guaranteed way to make money is to cater to the gold miners. some gold miners will strike it big, most wont. no way to tell ahead of time. so we make the platform that allows people the best chance of success and in turn the ecosystem will get the big successful projects
